knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
# 1.Create a Matrix
matrix(1:40)
matrix(1:40,ncol=5)
matrix(1:40,nrow=8)
matrix(1:40,ncol=5) ->mymatrix
mymatrix
mymatrix[4,mymatrix[4,] %% 3 ==0]
mymatrix[4,]%% 3 ==0
mymatrix[4,5]
# 2. Identify the Data Type
#Assign a numeric
a <- 13
#Find the datatype
mode(a)
typeof(a)

# Assign a character
y='homework'

#Find the datatype
mode(y)
typeof(y)

#3. Identity the Mean & Median
x <- c(14,5,3,22,-8,9,-3,45,12,43,8,6)
# Find Mean
result.mean <- mean(x) 
print(result.mean)

# Find Mean with Trim
result.mean <- mean(x,trim = 0.2)
print(result.mean)

# Find Median
median.result <- median(x)
print(median.result)

#4. Find the mode(s) 
getModes <- function(x) {
  uniqx <- unique(x)
  tab <- tabulate(match(x, uniqx))
  uniqx[tab == max(tab)]
}

x <-  c( 3,4,3,5,3,6,7,2,1,2,6,7,8,6)
result <- getModes(x)
print(result)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
